title: Position and Displacement
description: Understanding the concepts of position and displacement in kinematics, including vectors and mathematical representations.

sections.title: Introduction to Position and Displacement
sections.content: Position and displacement are fundamental concepts in kinematics that describe where an object is located and how its location changes over time. These concepts form the foundation for understanding velocity and acceleration.

sections.title: Position
sections.content:
Position refers to the location of an object relative to a chosen reference point (origin) in a given coordinate system. Position is a vector quantity, meaning it has both magnitude and direction.

In a Cartesian coordinate system, the position of a point in three-dimensional space is represented by the coordinates (x, y, z), where:

  • x is the distance along the x-axis
  • y is the distance along the y-axis
  • z is the distance along the z-axis

sections.title: Position Vector
sections.content:
The position vector (denoted by $\vec{r}$) points from the origin of the coordinate system to the object's location. In Cartesian coordinates, the position vector is:

\vec{r} = x\hat{i} + y\hat{j} + z\hat{k}

where $\hat{i}$, $\hat{j}$, and $\hat{k}$ are unit vectors in the x, y, and z directions, respectively.

sections.title: Displacement
sections.content:
Displacement is the change in position of an object. It is a vector quantity that points from the initial position to the final position. Displacement is defined as:

\vec{\Delta r} = \vec{r}_f - \vec{r}_i

where $\vec{r}_i$ is the initial position vector and $\vec{r}_f$ is the final position vector.

In Cartesian coordinates, the displacement vector is:

\vec{\Delta r} = (x_f - x_i)\hat{i} + (y_f - y_i)\hat{j} + (z_f - z_i)\hat{k}

sections.title: Displacement vs. Distance
sections.content:
It's important to distinguish between displacement and distance:

  • Displacement is a vector quantity that depends only on the starting and ending positions, regardless of the path taken.
  • Distance is a scalar quantity that measures the total length of the path traveled by an object, regardless of direction.

For example, if you walk 3 km east and then 4 km north, your displacement is 5 km northeast (calculated using the Pythagorean theorem), but the total distance traveled is 7 km (3 km + 4 km).

sections.title: Example: Calculating Displacement
sections.content: A particle moves from position (2 m, 3 m, 1 m) to position (5 m, 7 m, 4 m). Find the displacement vector and the magnitude of the displacement.
sections.solution:
The displacement vector is:

\vec{\Delta r} = \vec{r}_f - \vec{r}_i = (5 - 2)\hat{i} + (7 - 3)\hat{j} + (4 - 1)\hat{k} = 3\hat{i} + 4\hat{j} + 3\hat{k}

The magnitude of the displacement (the distance between the two points) is:

|\vec{\Delta r}| = \sqrt{3^2 + 4^2 + 3^2} = \sqrt{9 + 16 + 9} = \sqrt{34} \approx 5.83 \text{ m}

sections.title: Trajectory and Path
sections.content:
The trajectory or path of an object is the sequence of positions that the object occupies during its motion. Mathematically, we can represent the trajectory as a function of time:

\vec{r}(t) = x(t)\hat{i} + y(t)\hat{j} + z(t)\hat{k}

where x(t), y(t), and z(t) are the coordinates of the object at time t.

sections.title: Practice Problem: Calculating Displacement and Distance
sections.content:
A hiker walks 2 km east, then 3 km north, and finally 1 km west. Calculate:

  1. The final displacement vector from the starting point (in component form)
  2. The magnitude of the displacement
  3. The total distance traveled
sections.solution:
Let's define east as the positive x-direction and north as the positive y-direction.

1. The final displacement vector:

\vec{\Delta r} = (2 - 1)\hat{i} + 3\hat{j} = 1\hat{i} + 3\hat{j}

2. The magnitude of the displacement:

|\vec{\Delta r}| = \sqrt{1^2 + 3^2} = \sqrt{1 + 9} = \sqrt{10} \approx 3.16 \text{ km}

3. The total distance traveled:

\text{Distance} = 2 + 3 + 1 = 6 \text{ km}

sections.title: Relative Position
sections.content:
The relative position of object B with respect to object A is the position vector that points from A to B:

\vec{r}_{BA} = \vec{r}_B - \vec{r}_A

where $\vec{r}_A$ is the position vector of object A and $\vec{r}_B$ is the position vector of object B.

Relative position is important when analyzing systems with multiple objects or when changing reference frames.

sections.title: Summary
sections.content:
In this section, we covered:

  • Position as a vector quantity that describes location relative to an origin
  • The position vector and its representation in Cartesian coordinates
  • Displacement as the change in position
  • The difference between displacement and distance traveled
  • Trajectory as a function of time
  • Relative position between objects

These concepts provide the foundation for understanding velocity and acceleration, which we'll explore in the next sections.
